Re: Napier police shooting up an empty house on Saturday. https://t.co/1dIe6lRC2t
@_JTheory_ Yeah. Well, they're $10-$15 in bulk. Looks like minimum US$18 individually. https://t.co/rXhICjBBcI
@_JTheory_ U2F keys! They're great. The best 2FA. About $10ea. I use one everywhere that supports it (Google, Github, others)
@_JTheory_ Symantec at least have a public log of all certs they've issued. We have no idea what certs 100s of otheâ€¦ https://t.co/vMyR4X01vy
@_JTheory_ They have no such control. They control what CAs are trusted in Chrome, but that's it.
@_JTheory_ As it says, the purpose is "to more rapidly handle the SSL/TLS certificate needs of Google products". Not rely on another company
@_JTheory_ Their purpose isn't to prevent others from incorrectly issuing certs (they can't).
@_JTheory_ One big problem with PKI (e.g. for HTTPS) is how difficult this "trust chain" thing is for non-experts to understand.
@_JTheory_ Nope, because any of hundreds of CAs will still be able to issue a https://t.co/ytaOc2FRLE certificate.
@_JTheory_ Far more concerning are Root CAs like the Government of Thailand, trusted by Windows/IE/Edge. https://t.co/rpfzuloPOd
@_JTheory_ Any of those Root CAs could issue a cert to allow someone to impersonate a website and your browser would believe it.
@_JTheory_ No. Your browser trusts hundreds of root CAs, including Symantec. Google are just adding one more.
@Jenene NZ $516/week for a car. You're so Auckland.
@adzebill Quite the saga that one. No one held responsible.

@_JTheory_ Google running their own root CA doesn't address other root CAs wrongly issuing certificates.
@_JTheory_ The only surprising thing is that they didn't do this years ago.
